title.narrative: STITCH SRHR Tailor-made Information and Training to Contribute to Occupational Health and safety conditions of factory workers in the Ready-Made Garment Sector in Bangladesh

description.narrative: OKP-ICP-BGD-103153

The project has to contribute to the following impact and must achieve the outcomes and outputs os stated below. Long-term impact: 1. Better public and private health care, where SRHR information and services constitute on integral part of fhe health servïce package for RMG workers: 2. More respect for the sexual and reproductive rights of groups who are currently denied these rights, especially young (married and unmarried) girls. Medium-term impact: *Education system (TVET/HE) is of good quality, relevant and accessible (SDG4); *Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable (SDG 17); *Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce. Outcomes of the project: A. TVET/HE organisations (in the selected partner countries and in NL) perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment (in line with country / regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness); To that end, the following outputs must be achieved by the end of the project: 1. Integration of comprehensive SRHR education into vocational training of future garment workers. 2. Improved customized services by health care providers in garment factories to diverse groups of RMG workers including married/unmarried women and men, indigenous and other marginalised groups. 3. SRHR incorporated in the factory checklist of labour inspectors of DIFE under the Ministry of Labour 4. Integrated and coherent SRHR policies in the RMG sector. 5. Consolidation of institutional collaboration between the Government of Bangladesh, the BGMEA, vocational training institutes, the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, and other private/NGO organizations active in the field of SRHR in Bangladesh.

participating-org.narrative: Directorate General of Family Planning DGFP

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

comment.narrative: 07-08-2020: SRHR curriculum development for ASDC and DGFP is work in progress and is expected to be finalised in 2020
17-01-2022: We have developed 2 draft curricula: 1 for DGFP and 1 for ASDC but they're not yet formally finalized/ approved

title.narrative: A.O.1. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: - DGFP is providing importance to review their plans to ensure SRHR services, increase male engagement and male participation. DGFP is working together with some development partners and NGOs like UNFPA Bangladesh, Unicef Bangladesh, The Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, Path Finder International, Plan International, Save the Children, Red Orange, BKMEA and BGMEA to review the gender policies and guidelines including third gender. - ASDC, as the other knowledge institute, already has a gender policy in place which functions well.

22 representatives of 5 partner organisations (DGFP, ASDC, BGMEA, RO and IPDS ) have improved their gender awareness during the SRHR sensitization training. The training was about (among others) : “Gender, Sexuality and Rights”, including topics on: concepts of gender(gender and non-binary gender relations), gendered sexual experiences, gender based violence.

title.narrative: A.O.10. Diversity in management and teaching staff (i.e. balance in junior/senior staff, women/men, minorities)

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value:
All 5 partners of STITCH (VU, RO, IPDS, DGFP, VU) have diversity in management and teaching staff:
1. IPDS pay attention to the diversity of its staff and Management Board Members. Among the staff, IPDS has staff from four indigenous nationalities. They are : Garo, Khasi, Hajong and Banai. IPDS has an Indigenous Peoples' Policy fully focusing on the ethnic, religious and linguistic minority rights. 2. RedOrange believes in diversity and works for women empowerment. We especially invite females to apply for our positions (externally and internally) which is according to our HR Policy. More than 35% team members are female at this moment. In our line management, we have Senior staff, mid-level staff and female staff. 3. Yes, DGFP is paying duly attention from the beginning of its journey regarding diversity in management and teaching staff. DGFP is prioritizing the capacity development of Senior staff, mid-level staff and junior level staff to improve the quality of services on FP-MCH and Adolescent health care. For organizing the training DGFP include both male and female officers from the field-level and DGFP and from BKMEA; For venue selection we consider both govt and non-govt premises. For training sessions we include senior and junior, male and female officers from the field-level and DGFP. 4. Answer: We have a good balance at ASDC. Our management and project staffs are a mix of age, experience and men & women with significant participation/representation of minority. The governing and management committee is comprised of male and female (senior by age and diversified experience), executed by a very highly educated young team (CEO and implementation officials), the key positions like Communication Officer and the Admin officer are from the Hindu minority community. ASDC recruitments are also made based on the relevance of the post with academic-education background supported by experience & skills and evidence of quality of the person (job ability) and a gender balance is important (ASDC has 50:50 ratio at the head office and at the Training Centre it is 60m:40f with representation from minority community. As vocational training sector is dominated by male instructors other than garments trade. 5. VU has a dedicated ‘diversity office’. Society and with it our university community has a wide variety of gender, sexual orientation, nationalities, cultures, ways of thinking and religions. We train and educate our students to deal with these differences. So that they, as professionals, are able to view matters from a broader perspective, and as future leaders can make the difference in society. We strive for 'inclusive excellence' through four pillars, whereby students, teachers, lecturers and employees within VU use mutual differences to stimulate more creativity and talent development
This is not an indicator in the STITCH logframe

comment.narrative: 07-08-2020: In total 22 staff, representing DGFP/ ASDC/ BGMEA/ IPDS/ RO received training in SRHR and teaching methodologies which has provided them with relevant knowledge and skills to develop SRHR curricula and supporting innovative teaching tools. | 07-08-2020: 22 staff representing DGFP/ BGMEA/ ASDC/ IPDS/ RO participated in training on SRHR and teaching methodologies thus providing them with relevant knowledge and skills to develop SRHR curricula and innovative teaching tools

17-01-2022: The year 2020 focussed on the development of curricula. Various staff have been involved in a variety of activities which all contributed to gaining more knowledge/ skills on developing the new programmes: - ASDC 5 (3 f/ 2 m) - DGFP 9 (2 f/ 7 m) - IPDS 3 (1 f/ 2 m) - RO 7 (3 f/ 4 m) - VU (2 f/ 1 m)

title.narrative: A.E.2. Increased participation of students from minorities

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: Due to the Covid-19 pandemic all educational institutes in BGD have been closed for the entire year due to which we can't report on student numbers and/ or the participation of minorities among them

title.narrative: A.O.9. Number of organisations with improved policies or procedures to encourage access to education of minorities

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: 1. IPDS has an Indigenous Peoples' Policy fully focusing on the ethnic, religious and linguistic minority rights. 2. RedOrange promotes diversity and inclusion and also ensures an environment which is conductive for minorities. For our recruitment process we encourage all genders and communities to apply that is part of our HR Policy. 3. DGFP is providing importance to provide services to the minorities in the hill tracks areas and hard to reach areas. They involve minorities as service providers to ensure that the DGFP services run smoothly in the minority areas. Recently DGFP has developed an SRHR training manual for health services providers at RMG sector (as result of STITCH) in which information and priorities of minority groups and disabled persons have been incorporated. As humanity and equity is the first priority to the Bangladesh Government so minority peoples and peoples with disabilities are receiving services according to their need from the service centers at different tires.DGFP is also working together with some development partners and NGOs like UNFPA Bangladesh, Unicef Bangladesh, The Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, Path Finder International, Red Orange and local government to provide services to the Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh. 4. ASDC Answer: Education for All is the firm stand of the govt. ensured by the Constitution of Bangladesh (Article 8(2) - "equality clause" contemplated under Article 27, "equality of opportunity ,contemplated under Article 29 contemplated under Article 32, interpreted in Article 17). It is applicable with exception of the domain of the religious schools (Madrasa for pure Islamic Education, or similar with Buddhist schools). So no body, or organization can deny the rights of the minorities - religious or ethnic or so). But there is a social stigma on enrollment of the third gender/hijra community with some exceptions. Once in 2018, ASDC took all preparations for providing skills/vocat ...

title.narrative: A.O.12. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is conducive for minorities

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: All 5 organisations of the STITCH project have this! See more detailed information provided in the answers on gender and minorities.

title.narrative: A.O.11. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is gender sensitive

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: All 5 partners of STITCH (VU, RO, IPDS, DGFP, VU) 1. IPDS follows procedures to recruit women and men staff. IPDS policy approved for consideration of 50% female staff. IPDS has a Gender Policy and IPDS is a gender sensitive organization. 2. RedOrange has Sexual Harassment Policy, Gender Policy, Anti-harassment Policy among other Policies which ensure the gender sensitive environment at workplace. For example, a focal person for Sexual Harassment Policy where any team member can report and every team member are oriented about this. 3. As a government organization, DGFP is following the sustaining policies/procedures of the Government. These are not gender specific however well describe gender issues and women empowerment. DGFP follows the population policy, current health policies, Five Years Operational Plan, Adolescent Health Strategy where the gender issues are focused as per priority. There is a good practice of DGFP to conduct session in a training program to ensure gender sensitive environment, the resources person always pay their attention during delivering their sessions as well as regarding topics, they also practice group works, role play, quiz, and interesting brain storming plays among participants to ensure convenient atmosphere in the classroom. Moreover, for selecting venues we consider safe and comfortable areas, good transportations facilities and separate lavatory for gens and ladies. 4. Yes, ASDC has a Gender policy which is part of the HR Policy. 5. Yes, VU has a Gender and Diversity policy and various toolkits which assist developing towards a university which becomes even more inclusive and diverse. WO&MEN is a network of VU employees, committed to improving gender equality within the VU.

title.narrative: A.O.5. Number of organisations that have developed and implemented a system to regularly survey the satisfaction of students, short courses participants, graduates and/or employers

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: Both ASDC and DGFP have a checklist/ evaluation forms that they put to use to evaluate satisfaction

title.narrative: A.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: Last year we reported 0 beneficiaries in society reached but in fact we already reached out to 'society' through our kick-off of the project. Secondly we invited indigeneous stakeholders to inform them about the project and hear their view on the draft curricula. We literally counted all representatives and didn't include a multiplier effect (e.g. to how many people have these 83 people talked about the project?)

title.narrative: A.R.2. Number of relevant publications (level, gender, inclusion)
A.E.6. Number of students enrolled in revised/newly developed study programmes
A.R.3. Number of relevant innovations

comment.narrative: 17-01-2022: We developed i) 6 animations (=video) on SRHR for DGFP and ii) a package of 100 illustrations on SRHR for the new SRHR curriculum of DGFP

title.narrative: III. Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce
III.I.1. % of alumni who state that they have applied in their workplace the knowledge and skills gained from the interventions

comment.narrative: Average of 60 and 95%
Average of 70 and 90%
Average of 80 and 85%

FNS.2 Promote agricultural growth

FNS.2.3. Number of family farms (sub-sector, male/female, age: % < 35) whose farming enterprise became more resilient to shocks

SRHR.1 Better information and greater freedom of choice for young people about their sexuality
SRHR.1.2. Number of young people reached with comprehensive, correct information on sexuality, HIV/AIDS, STIs, pregnancy and contraception
SRHR.1.3. Number of health facilities that adopt and implement youth-friendly SRHR and HIV/AIDS services
SRHR.1.4. % of women (20-24yr) who were married or in union before ages 15 and 18
SRHR.1.5. % of girls and women (15-49yr) who have undergone FGM/C
SRHR.1.6. Condom use by young people at last high-risk sex
SRHR1.1. Number of youth who participate in policy and decision-making bodies and perceive their participation as meaningful
SRHR.2 Improved access to contraceptives and medicines
SRHR.2.1. Total Dutch ODA for R&D for essential SRH and HIV/AIDS medicines, vaccines and commodities
SRHR.2.2. Number of and type of new user-friendly SRH products on the market
SRHR.2.3. Number of children fully immunized
SRHR.2.4. Number of additional women and girls using modern contraceptives
SRHR.2.5. Number of couples protected by various contraceptives over a 1-year period (couple-years protection)
SRHR.2.6. Number of and % of eligible PLHIV receiving ART2
SRHR.2.7. Number of people receiving interventions against TB, malaria, hepatitis and NTDs

SROL.1 Human Security: Reduced levels of violence and levels of fear experienced
SROL.1.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report a reduction in violent incidents in the area where they live
SROL.1.10. Number of national/local authorities supported in addressing root causes and triggers of violent extremism, particularly through SRoL (push factors)
SROL.1.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report they are feeling secure in the area where they live
SROL.1.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report increased levels of trust in security sector actors
SROL.1.4. Number of beneficiaries who report having received positive service provision by formal and informal authorities with regard to human security
SROL.1.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report that they have a more negative perception about violent extremist organisations
SROL.1.6. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who report on reduced levels of violence and fear experienced
SROL.1.7. Number of policy influencing initiatives aimed at long-term stabilisation

SROL.1.8. Number of beneficiaries with relevant knowledge and skills to support the formal security sector to strengthen reform processes that ensure increased accountability, transparency and gendersensitivity
SROL.1.9. Number of community-based security sector providers that have improved knowledge and skills to offer effective, accountable and responsive service to citizens and government

SROL.2 Rule of Law Strengthened: Citizens are better able to access their rights through fair, efficient, impartial, independent and accountable institutions
SROL.2.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) with access to justice [note: this is an official DGIS-indicator] (separate out: no. of women who present cases of sexual violence or domestic abuse)
SROL.2.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights and/or of how to address justice problems (claim, defend, and or recover rights)
SROL.2.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who access transitional justice mechanisms
SROL.2.4. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights
SROL.2.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who have improved access to their rights and judicial service facilities.
SROL.2.6. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to support policies that promote increase to access to justice

SROL.2.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to provide (policy) advice on specialised topics such as informal justice, commercial justice, rehabilitation, juvenile justice, sharia, gender issues
SROL.2.8. Number of justice innovations (e.g. scenario planning)

SROL.3 Peace processes & political governance: States, regional and local authorities and societies at large are able to effectively prevent and resolve conflict in a non-violent and inclusive manner
SROL.3.1. Number conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures by the programme (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel that community grievances of targeted groups (e.g. women, youth or a specific ethnic group) are effectively addressed (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.3. Participation (and satisfaction) in governance processes (political decision-making, mediation and dialogue) by representation of various groups, with special reference to women and youth
SROL.3.4. Perception on accountability/transparency of governance structures
SROL.3.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.3.6. Number of national and/or local level conflict resolution and peacebuilding mechanisms supported
SROL.3.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support policy influencing of incountry and regional conflict resolution and peacebuilding interventions

SROL.3.8. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support interventions at national level to increase civil society engagement and at local level to increase community engagement in political decision-making
SROL.3.9. Number of beneficiaries with improved capacity for policy influencing on aspects of political governance and state building

SROL.4 Social and economic reconstruction: Income generating and livelihoods opportunities to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration
SROL.4.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.4.10. Number of people supported to improve their income/ livelihood opportunities
SROL.4.2. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who started a business / self-employment activity and sustained it 6 months after they started

SROL.4.3. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who indicate that their business / self-employment activities (which existed already before the grantees' interventions) have grown over the last 6 months
SROL.4.4. (disaggregated) Number of trained/supported programme beneficiaries who have become employed
SROL.4.5. (disaggregated) Number of direct jobs supported by targeted companies
SROL.4.6. (disaggregated) Number of communities in programme areas that have adopted and are implementing livelihood protection strategies
SROL.4.7. Number of people with improved income in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.8. Number of people using new or improved water points in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.9. Number of direct jobs supported
